conclusion: Use principles of ideal gas behavior and relationship between pressure, volume, and temperature.
Diagram shows gas moving from state A to state C, then back to state A, and finally back to state B.
Identify initial and final states: initial state A at 200K, final state C at 200K.
Temperature remains constant, so gas follows ideal gas law: PV = nRT.
Since temperature is constant, volume ratio VC/VA = VA/VB, implying pressure ratio PC/PA = PA/PB.
Process from C to A involves decrease in volume from 5L to 2L, so VC/VA = 2/5.
Using ideal gas law, work done by gas is W = PΔV; since temperature is constant, work done equals change in volume.
Calculate work done by gas: VC/VA = 2/5, so W = P × ΔV = P × (5 - 2) = 3P.
Given pressure P as 4 × 10^5 Pa, work done by gas is 3 × 4 × 10^5 = 1.2 × 10^6 J.
Work done by external environment is difference between work done by gas and work done by gas on environment, which is 1.2 × 10^6 J.
Work done by external environment equals change in internal energy, ΔU = W = 1.2 × 10^6 J.
Internal energy change ΔU = nRT; since temperature is constant, ΔU = nRT = 200 × 8.314 × 200.
Calculate number of moles n: temperature is 200K, n = ΔU/(R × 200) = 200 × 8.314/200 = 8.314.
Substitute values to find work done by external environment: W = 1.2 × 10^6.
Work done by external environment is 1.2 × 10^6.
